title_full: SAAS02-BP01 Bind user identity to tenant identity as a first-class construct
title: Bind user identity to tenant identity as a first-class construct
description: Create a SaaS identity that connects user identity directly to tenant context. Inject custom claims into user attributes during registration that hold information about the user's relationship to a tenant. These custom claims become part of the identity signature, connecting users directly with a tenant as a first-class construct. Use JWT tokens that include tenant context to pass tenant information through all layers of the architecture without requiring roundtrips to another service.

title_full: SAAS02-BP02 Flow tenant context through all architecture layers via JWT tokens
title: Flow tenant context through all architecture layers via JWT tokens
description: Pass JWT tokens containing tenant context as bearer tokens in the header of each request to microservices. This allows services to acquire and apply tenant context without calling another service, avoiding latency and bottlenecks. When calling downstream microservices, pass the JWT in the request header to flow tenant context across all service calls. This approach works with Amazon Cognito or other identity providers.

title_full: SAAS02-BP03 Implement tenant isolation as a foundational requirement
title: Implement tenant isolation as a foundational requirement
description: Treat tenant isolation as a foundational element of SaaS that is not optional. Every system delivering a multi-tenant solution must ensure tenant resources are isolated. Authentication and authorization alone are not equal to isolation - getting past login screens does not mean isolation is achieved. Crossing tenant boundaries in any form represents a significant and potentially unrecoverable event for a SaaS business. Establish clear high-level isolation requirements that guide teams as they define the isolation footprint.

title_full: SAAS02-BP04 Control isolation through shared mechanisms outside developer code
title: Control isolation through shared mechanisms outside developer code
description: Do not leave isolation enforcement to service developers. While developers should never intentionally introduce code that violates isolation, expecting they will never unintentionally cross a tenant boundary is unrealistic. Control scoping of access to resources through shared mechanisms responsible for applying isolation rules outside the view of developers. Use shared libraries, modules, or lightweight frameworks to manage the process of acquiring scoped context.

title_full: SAAS02-BP05 Implement isolation for both siloed and pooled resource models
title: Implement isolation for both siloed and pooled resource models
description: Understand that isolation is not limited to resource-level constructs where you have separate databases, compute instances, accounts, or VPCs for each tenant. Even in environments where resources are shared, there are ways to achieve isolation through logical constructs enforced by runtime policies. Do not equate isolation with having siloed resources. In shared resource models, isolation can be enforced through IAM policies, row-level security, or other runtime mechanisms.

title_full: SAAS02-BP06 Build custom isolation solutions when out-of-the-box options don't exist
title: Build custom isolation solutions when out-of-the-box options don't exist
description: If there is no out-of-the-box isolation solution for your specific requirements, build it yourself. While AWS IAM and other tools can simplify the path to tenant isolation, there might be scenarios where your isolation model is not directly addressed by existing tools or technology. The absence of a clear solution should not represent an opportunity to lower your isolation requirements. Domain-specific requirements in high compliance industries may impose constraints requiring specific isolation approaches.

title_full: SAAS02-BP07 Use separate Amazon Cognito user pools for per-tenant identity customization
title: Use separate Amazon Cognito user pools for per-tenant identity customization
description: Consider using separate Amazon Cognito user pools for each tenant to customize the identity experience including password policies and multi-factor authentication. When using this approach, create a mapping between user IDs and corresponding user pools managed by the user management service. This provides flexibility for tenant-specific security requirements while maintaining a unified authentication experience.

title_full: SAAS02-BP08 Create IAM policies during onboarding to support tenant isolation
title: Create IAM policies during onboarding to support tenant isolation
description: During tenant onboarding, create IAM policies needed to support the isolation requirements of each tenant. The user management service should create users in the identity provider and create any IAM policies that establish the isolation boundaries for the new tenant. These policies become part of the tenant's security footprint and are applied at runtime to scope access to resources.
